advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert show the built-in user menu and system status.<br><br> The right located system is the dual-drive version.<br> The left one is the 10 MB hard-disk version.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote>April 1987 price list, including VAT.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACE 100 ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> LOGABAX STICKER</strong></font><br><blockquote>"What a quantum leap, Logabax!"<br> "I would say even more, what a quantum leap!"<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://tintinomanie.chez.tiscali.fr/</b> © Moulinsart</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD (MAR. 86)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said<br><br><font color="#666666"> The electric typewriter's days are numbered. Because now there's a machine that put real wordprocessing power within everyone's reach.<br> The Amstrad PCW 8256 is a complete word-processor and a powerful computer in one unit.<br> And it's unbelievably low price includes a screen with built-in disc drive, keyboard, printer and word processing software...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> THE FIRST M20 VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>This Olivetti ancestor, also called M20, was born in 1920...<br> To note the superb design all the young italian secretaries were in love of! <p class="petitgris">Thanks to Karl-Heinz - www.sharpmz.org</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"A rainbow in your office"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The family advice"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Thank you boss !" <br><br> The ad incite employees to ask their boss to buy these Apricot systems...clever.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>"From 1 to 16 users"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>>  U.S. AD #2 (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Despite the M20 was neither software nor hardware compatible with any other computer, Olivetti had to prove that it had more computing power at a smaller pice than any competitor. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">You may not have thought of all the reasons for buying a personal computer. There are exciting games, of course, but what about financial management, household records, even income tax? You need a versatile, sophisticated machine that's as limitless as your imagination. You need the Compucolor ll...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>German advert for the Philips Odyssey 200 model.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.dieterkoenig.at/ccc/" target="_blank">Dieter Koening</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The personal computer at the top of its form.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert was for the Serie 5 and the ACS-8000 systems.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert introduced three new Digital professional computers: the <b>Professional 300 Series</b>, the <b>DECmate II</b>, and the <b>Rainbow 100</b> <br><br> Advert said: <br><br> <font color="#666666">All that personal computers needed were a few professional standards. <br><br> Until now, manufacturer have made personal computers that were a hopeful compromise between home and use business. But now, Digital Equipment Corporation offers the first personal computers designed and built strictly for professional use. And since different professionals have different needs, Digital is introducing not one, but three personal computers made to professional standards.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This guy has so much power in his hands that he has attracted two girls (so far) in his swimming-pool ! <br><br> Notice the classical symbol of the 80s adverts : the glass of orange juice with a straw...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>"With a cool teacher, computers is a child game" <br><br> "Alice, the Basic teacher"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FLYER</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.console-picture-page.de" target="_blank">www.console-picture-page.de</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (SEPT. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Arcades games in an armchair"</blockquote>

computer.coprocessor: Game selection, Ball Angle (20?/40?), Ball Speed (fast/slow), Bar Size (small/large), Auto serve (on/off) & Power switch
computer.description:
The Grandstand T.V. Game 3000 is a classic pong system sold in U.K. It can be also found under different other brands worldwide. It's in fact the same model as the T.V. Game Model 2000 but with a colour display (Model 3000 is in black & white).
The system itself seems to have been made in Korea. The electronic board is labeled "F'GAMATIC-7600". Indeed many Gamatic 7600 systems identical to this one can be found worldwide, the earliest one being a japanese Gamatic 7600 system released in 1976.
The case design is not particularly original: black rectangle with two detachable controllers and a wide control panel at the top. The controllers are also rectangular with a dial to move the bat on screen and a red button each, one to serve (left player) and the other to reset the game (right player).
As mostly all the systems powered by the TMS-1965 chipset from Texas Instruments, the T.V. Game Model 3000 offers 4 pong games : Football, Squash, Tennis and Practice delivered by this specialised chip (the TMS-1965 was pin-to-pin compatible with the more popular AY-3-8500 chip from General Instruments)
On the control panel can be found the usual setting switches: ball speed (slow/fast), automatic service (on/off), game selection, rebound angle (20?/40?), bat size (small/big) and power switch. The system can be powered by six CM2 battery cells or through an external power supply (9v DC, 360 mW).
computer.keyboard: Two detachable controllers with one knob each
computer.name: T.V. Game Model 3000
computer.ports: RF TV video output, power in
